Subject: Re: Bilateral Symmetry and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=DguRw7JJxV-gn3Jk8GlkNU7Gola4AQIT7wPc2qI9tovGd5EpJ8_F

Hi Derek, I like your choice of project.  It addresses the big 
assumption =
that symmetry is beneficial to a lot of cognitive 
processing.  By making s=
ymmetry explicity, I think it allows you to 
get to the heart of the matter=
.  It also does a really good job of 
fitting NEAT into the context of your=
 cognitive science program.

I'm a little unsure if I'm covering all the po=
ssibilities properly 
in my mind. I think a few activation examples might h=
elp make it 
concrete.  For example, what if I made a network with just one=
 
symmetric input and the none asymmetric output?  Is that different 
from =
a network with an asymmetric input and an asymmetric output?  
How do you r=
ead a symmetric output?  Is it interpreted as two 
outputs?

Something that=
 would be a great debugging tool is a visualization 
that shows the transla=
tion from the specially-encoded network to its 
normal graph (i.e. two side=
-by-side pictures).  In the second 
picture, "symmetric" pieces would now b=
e (I assume) pairs of 
structures, one on each side.  Then maybe you could =
see the 
contralateral crossing visually, among other things.  But it would=
 
also make sure that the system means what you think it means.

I once had=
 a different idea about symmetry in NEAT, which was to 
take a NEAT network=
 that is "one-sided" and reflect the entire 
network (with the reflection h=
aving all new historical markings), 
and then concatenate the two networks =
(the original and its 
reflection) into one genome.  By "one-sided" I mean =
those irritating 
bots that tend to only do thing by turning way way or ano=
ther (or 
things like that).   What I was wondering is whether once NEAT 
d=
iscovers a one-sided strategy, it can be fairly easily duplicated 
on the o=
ther side with little difficulty.

Of course I can see problems there.  It =
could create an 
unintentional opponent process that causes the network to =
fight with 
itself in some cases and end up doing nothing.  The failure cas=
es 
can be subtle and hard to visualize, but I think that's true in your 
a=
pproach as well, which is why I bring this up.  What I'm wondering 
is whet=
her what you're doing better avoids the potentially sloppy ad-
hocness of m=
y idea.  I'm also wondering what you see as the pluses 
and minuses in gene=
ral, since you've been thinking about this a lot 
recently.

Anyway, I'm su=
re I'll have more thoughts but hearing more about 
activating your networks=
 would give me a better intuitive 
understanding.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> 
> 
> Just tho=
ught I'd post an update on what Philip and I have been 
working on
> lately=
, to get some feedback, but also to help me articulate the
> implementation=
 and some of the ideas behind it (since I'm in grad 
school now
> and will =
have to explain this to a lot of people soon anyway).
> 
> 
> 
> I have to =
do a first year project as part of the PhD program I'm 
in right
> now, Cog=
nitive Science at the University of Louisiana at 
Lafayette.  I
> decided t=
o focus on a particular aspect of indirect encoding in 
the context
> of NE=
AT, specifically bilateral symmetry.  Most animals exhibit a 
high
> degree=
 of bilateral symmetry in their overall body plan, as well 
as their
> neur=
al systems.  It seemed like a logical starting point for a 
foray into
> in=
direct encoding.
> 
> 
> 
> Anyway, I'm interested in several theoretical q=
uestions:
> 
> 
> 
> To what extent is bilateral symmetry in an agent's neu=
ral system 
necessary?
> 
> And for what kinds of cognitive tasks?
> 
> To =
what extent is contralateral connectivity (connections which 
cross the
> m=
idline of the neural system, i.e., are interhemispheric) 
important, as
> o=
pposed to ipsilateral connectivity (connections which do not 
cross the
> m=
idline, i.e., are intrahemispheric)?
> 
> 
> 
> To try to start answering s=
ome of these questions, we extended 
NEAT in the
> following ways:
> 
> 
> =

> Before, the experimenter would declare the number of input and 
output u=
nits.
> Now there are four parameters:
> 
> 
> 
> inputs.asymmetrical
> 
> =
outputs.asymetrical
> 
> inputs.symmetrical
> 
> outputs.symmetrical
> 
> 
=
> 
> I'll use XOR as a running example.  To simply run XOR as before, 
the
=
> experimenter would declare 3 asymmetrical inputs (for the two data 
input=
s
> and the bias), and one asymmetrical output.  Per the NEAT 
paradigm, th=
ey
> would initially be fully-connected with feedforward connections, 
all =
with
> different random initial weights.  Everything else would work as 
be=
fore.
> 
> 
> 
> To run XOR under a symmetrical condition, the experimenter=
 would 
declare 1
> asymmetrical input (bias), 1 symmetrical input (for the=
 2 data 
inputs), and
> 1 asymetrical output. Let's call the asymmetrical i=
nput, neuron 0, 
the
> symmetrical neuron 1, and the output neuron 2.
> 
> =

> 
> When constructing the initial network, all asymmetrical neurons 
will=
 default
> to the "left" of the network.  So the network now has a spatial =

structure,
> whereas before it was arbitrary.  So neuron 0 is on on the le=
ft, 
along with
> output neuron 2.  When reading the chromosome and buildin=
g the 
network,
> neuron 1 is split into 2 copies: 1left and 1right, with i=
dentical
> attributes.  The initial network is still fully-connected feed-
=
forward, but
> there are only 2 connection genes in the intial chromosome: =

asymmetrical
> connection 4 (which connects 0 and 2), and symmetrical conn=
ection 
5 (which
> connects 1 and 2).  When constructed, connection 4 makes=
 a single 
connection
> with a random initial weight.  Connection 5 makes 2=
 connections, 
5left and
> 5right, connecting 1left to 2 and 1right to 2, a=
nd both 
connections have the
> same random initial weight.
> 
> 
> 
> Hope=
 that makes sense.  There are lots of ways to encode bilateral 
symmetry.
>=
 We chose to make symmetry an attribute of individual genes.  It 
may not b=
e
> the most biologically-inspired encoding, but we felt that it fit 
best =
within
> the context of NEAT and allowed for good control over the amount 
=
and type of
> symmetry in the evolving population.
> 
> 
> 
> So all neuron=
 genes now have a symmetry attribute, and all 
connections have
> 2 new att=
ributes, symmetry and lateralization (indicating whether 
they cross
> the =
midline or not).
> 
> 
> 
> Anyway, about mutations:
> 
> 
> 
> Perturb con=
nection weight remains unchanged, although if it 
affects a
> symmetrical c=
onnection, it will affect both copies created in the 
resulting
> network.
=
> 
> 
> 
> Add neuron basically works the same as well.  If a neuron is 
mu=
tated on top
> of an existing asymmetrical connection, it creates the new n=
euron 
and the
> new incoming and outgoing connections per NEAT, and all 3 =
new 
features are
> asymmetric.  If the mutation occurs on top of a symmetr=
ic 
connection, the
> new resulting neurons and connections will have the s=
ame symmetry 
and
> lateralization attributes of the connection gene they r=
eplaced.
> 
> 
> 
> Add connection mutations are fairly complicated.  There=
 are 2 new 
mutation
> rates, which control the amount of symmetry and late=
ralization in 
the newly
> mutated connections.  First, the add connection =
mutation rate 
determines how
> many new connections should be added.  Of t=
hose, the symmetry rate
> determines the ratio that are symmetric.  Of each=
 of those two 
ratios, the
> lateralization rate determines the ratio of ne=
w 
contralateral/ipsilateral
> connections.
> 
> 
> 
> New connections betw=
een 2 asymmetrical neurons are asymmetrical.  
New
> connections between an=
 asymmetrical neuron and a symmetrical 
neuron can
> either be asymmetrical=
 or symmetrical.
> 
> 
> 
> For a mutation between 2 symmetrical neurons, t=
here are four 
actual neurons
> in the resulting network, and we allow 6 po=
ssible types of 
connectivity to
> mutate:
> 
> 
> 
> symmetrical/ipsilater=
al    ||
> 
> symmetric/contralateral    X
> 
> asymmetric/ipsilateral left=
   |-
> 
> asymmetric/ipsilateral right   -|
> 
> asymmetric/contralateral =
left  /
> 
> asymmetric/contralateral right  \
> 
> 
> 
> So by adjusting t=
he symmetry rate, we can control the amount of 
symmetry
> that evolves amo=
ng new connections, and by adjusting the 
lateralization
> rate, we can con=
trol the amount of connectivity that crosses the 
midline of
> the network.=

> 
> 
> 
> I'm sure there are weaknesses to this encoding scheme (as I'm s=
ure 
some of
> you will point out...please do).  It's now nearly completely=
 
implemented in
> ANJI (though there's still a lot of testing to be done, =
and we're 
not going
> to release it yet).
> 
> 
> 
> I'm applying it to an=
 active vision symmetry detection task 
(discriminating
> between sets of s=
ymmetrical and asymmetrical letters).  I've got 
some
> preliminary results=
, but I'm not particularly confident that 
everything's
> working the way i=
t's supposed to.  This testbed is nice, since it 
involves
> both control a=
spects and pattern processing, so I'm interested to 
see if
> there are qua=
litative differences in the way symmetrically-encoded 
and
> asymmetrically=
-encoded populations solve the problem (or fail to 
solve the
> problem).
>=
 
> 
> 
> Anyway, I hope to present this research at GECCO this summer, but=
 
I thought
> I'd expose the group to it as well and see what thoughts peop=
le 
might have.
>
